title: Twin Rivers Classic Thursday Roundup
text:
Twin Rivers Classic Thursday Roundup NEAL DENTON, ndenton@baxterbulletin.com 10:29 p.m. CDT October 22, 2015 Buy Photo Cotter's Taran Eaton puts up a shot over Lead Hill's Zack Cain during the Warriors' 75-54 victory Thursday night at Norfork's Twin Rivers Classic. (Photo: Neal Denton/The Baxter Bulletin) Buy Photo 60 CONNECT 3 TWEET LINKEDIN COMMENT EMAIL MORE 
NORFORK — After a third-quarter buzzer-beater had pulled Lead Hill the closest it had been since the first period, the Cotter Warriors responded with strong defense to claim a season-opening victory. 
The Warriors outscored the Tigers 22-5 in the fourth quarter, running to a 75-54 win Thursday night at the Twin Rivers Classic at Bobby D. Hulse Gymnasium. 
Lead Hill point guard Trey Rogers knocked down a long 3-pointer to bring the Tigers within 53-49 to end the third quarter, but Cotter answered with the first nine of the fourth. 
Dawson Burns converted a traditional 3-point play, and Shawn White and Maddux Adams each buried 3-pointers to send the Warrior lead to 62-49 with 6:30 remaining. After 1-of-2 free-throw shooting by Lead Hill's Cooper Lemon, Taran Eaton concluded an 11-1 Cotter run with a jumper to make it 64-50. The Tigers never climbed any closer than 12 the rest of the way. 
Adams and Matthew Gorbet led Cotter with 17 points apiece, while Eaton and Burns also found double figures with 11 and 10, respectively. 
Rogers led Lead Hill with 19 points, while Tim Kalocai and Lemon added 14 and 11, respectively. 
Cotter ran to a 12-6 lead, but Lead Hill climbed within two and trailed just 16-14 when Landon Martin and Maddux Adams each scored to send the Warriors' lead back to six to end the first quarter. 
Martin also scored to open the second, pushing Cotter's lead to eight for the first time, and after a Lead Hill basket, Adams drained a 3-pointer for a 25-16 advantage. After Lead Hill's Zack Cain scored, Adams converted an old-fashioned 3-point play to stretch the lead to double digits for the first time at 28-18. Cotter ended the 15-4 run with a trey by Hunter Dearmore to push the lead to 13. 
Lead Hill did not go away, climbing within single digits and getting as close as 34-27 in the second quarter. The Warriors responded with seven straight — five by Dawson Burns — to take a 41-27 advantage. 
The Tigers still didn't go away, climbing within 43-32 by the halftime break. 
WARRIORS (1-0) 
Gorbet 17, Adams 17, Eaton 11, Burns 10, White 7, Dearmore 6, Martin 4, Kapshandy 3. 
TIGERS (0-2) 
Rogers 19, Kalocai 14, Lemon 11, Cain 5, Turner 3, Ballestri 2. 
COTTER 20 23 10 22 - 75 
LEAD HILL 14 18 17 5 - 54 
Senior girls 
Norfork 75, 
Lead Hill 30 
Marleigh Dodson scored Norfork's first 21 points of the night and went on to pour in a game-high 28 to lead the Lady Panthers to their first victory of the season. 
Norfork led just 11-8 after one quarter, but got going in the second with a 30-point quarter. No Lady Panther other than Dodson scored until Rile yScalf buried a 3-pointer with 4:42 left in the second quarter, stretching the hosts' lead to 24-11. Buy Photo 
Norfork's Matty Dillard pressures Lead Hill's Talen Rogers during the Lady Panthers' 75-30 victory. (Photo: Neal Denton/The Baxter Bulletin) 
Dodson scored 13 in the second quarter, where Norfork outscored Lead Hill 30-9. Scalf hit another trey during the frame, and Lauren Staples and Matty Dillard each added 3-pointers as well as the Lady Panthers took a 41-17 advantage into the halftime break. 
Norfork received eight points from Makayla Irby in the third quarter, including two 3-pointers. The Lady Panthers led 57-28 after three, and Dillard's second trey of the night invoked the running-clock mercy rule for the rest of the fourth quarter. 
Staples had six points off steals in the fourth, and Greve added a 3 from the top of the arc as the Lady Panthers went on a 15-0 run to end the game. 
The Lady Panthers return to action Saturday when they play their third game in the Classic. 
LADY TIGERS (1-1) 
Cain 9, Clary 8, Huebner 5, Kuykendall 4, Rogers 3, Sprinkle 1. 
LADY PANTHERS (1-1) 
Dodson 28, Irby 9, Staples 9, Greve 7, Scalf 6, Dillard 6, Sisco 6, Belding 2, Gaskin 2. 
LEAD HILL 8 9 11 2 - 30 
NORFORK 11 30 16 18 - 75 
Senior boys 
Viola 65, 
Southside-Bee Branch 36 
A 17-0 first-half run by the Longhorns was answered by the Hornets, but another run of 18-2 in the second half was not, giving Viola its first victory of the season. 
Viola (1-1) held a 10-6 lead after one quarter and led just 13-8 when it scored 17 straight. A 3-pointer by Alex Waltrip started the flurry, and a trey by Dalton Brown capped the run to give the Longhorns a 30-8 advantage. 
The Hornets met the run with a 12-3 run of their own to end the half, pulling within 33-20 at the intermission. Viola mounted an 18-2 run to begin the second half, receiving 3-pointers from Steffahn Smith, Dalton Lund, Brown and Keagan Dunn to push to a 51-22 lead. Buy Photo 
Viola's Dalton Lund is pressured by three Southside-Bee Branch players during the Longhorns' victory at the Twin Rivers Classic. (Photo: Neal Denton/The Baxter Bulletin) 
Viola led 56-26 at the end of three, invoking the running-clock mercy rule for the fourth. 
Smith led all scorers with 22 points, while Lund added 13 and Brown notched 11. Jadon Price paced Southside-Bee Branch with 12 points. 
Senior girls 
Viola 25 
Free-throw shooting played a key factor as the Lady Longhorns suffered a second straight loss. 
Viola shot just 3 of 17 from the foul line, while the Lady Hornets shot 26 of 32 from the stripe. Viola, which fell to Tuckerman in its season opener on Tuesday night, falls to 0-2 on the season, while the Lady Hornets improve to 1-1. 
Both teams started slowly as the Lady Hornets took a 5-2 lead after one quarter. A steal and layup by Amanda Martin knotted the score at 5-5 early in the second, and the teams were tied 7-7 when Southside took the lead for good. 
The Lady Hornets led 16-9 at the half and 28-19 after three quarters. Martin hit a 3-pointer to being the fourth, but the lady Longhorns could climb only as close as 31-25 in the final stanza.
